--------------92C3083E44FE54D9D0853AD5
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hi Faith,

thanks for your response, I am sorry for the pure docs, I wrote JavaDoc
comments
and appended generated JavaDocs, I hope this helps better to start with the
file-diff
extension. I also wrote simple example, showing the usage of assertFile
functions.

As I needed more than just comparion of two files, I didn't think about the
simple
assertFile("file1", :file2") function, but definitly it belongs there (and
now I added it).
So, please take updated version of this extension from appended ZIP archive,
try
example (its usage is described in readme.html) and/or read more info from
JavaDocs.

Maybe you will find some kinds of assertFile functions needless, I would like
to
discuss it in wider audience, because I think that file-diff capability
significantly
improves the JUnit framework.

Also I would like to find better diff implementations written in Java, which
will produce
results in human readable form. The SimpleDiff doesn't produce output at all
and the
NativeDiff relies on the native application.

Any other comments are more than welcomed.

Thank you,
Vita


faith@... wrote:

> Vitezslav,
>
> Thank-you for the JUnit file-diff extension.  The capability is
> exactly what I need.
>
> I am having a bit of a problem implementing it. If you could give me
> an short example, I would appreciate it. Here is an outline of what I
> have tried so far.
>
> In the original post you requested an assert that would take two file
> names and return a boolean. So, before reading .java files, I tried
> the following and was told that there were not enough arguments:
> assertFile("file1", "file2");
>
> Then being stubborn I tried:
> assertFile("file1", "file2", null);
>
> This ran fine, however, file1 and file2 did not exist.
>
> If you could provide an example of the diff parameter that needs to
> be passed, I would appreciate it. The html mentioned a
> junit.diff.SimpleDiff.  I would like to use this.  However, I cannot
> find it in the package.
>
> Once again, I would like to say that this is an excellent idea.  It
> would be nice to see the documentation expanded.
>
> Faith
>
